docTitle.titlePart: Pharmacokinetics of a Novel One-Armed Antibody to C-Met in Mice, Rats, and Monkeys

byline.docAuthor: A. E. Reyes II, H. Xiang, B. Bender, P. Haughney, A. Oldendorp, I. Nijem, T. Davancaze, E. Mai, J. Young, L. A. Damico

front.div:
Purpose.
MetMAb is a novel, aglycosylated, monovalent, humanized, monoclonal antibody produced in E.coli that binds to the
receptor tyrosine kinase c-Met. It is being evaluated as a potential therapy for human cancer. The purpose of these studies
was to evaluate the pharmacokinetics (PK) of MetMAb in mice, rats, and monkeys, to estimate PK parameters in humans.
Methods.
MetMAb was administered as a single intravenous (IV) bolus dose to Athymic Nude Mice, Sprague Dawley and NIH Nude
Rats, and Cynomolgus Monkeys at doses ranging from 0.5-30mg/kg. Serum samples were collected over 5 weeks. Serum
MetMAb concentrations were determined using an ELISA. Serum concentration-time profiles were used to estimate PK
parameters using WinNonlin software. Estimation of MetMAb PK parameters in humans was determined by allometric
scaling using data from all three species or by a species invariant time method using data from the monkey only.
Results.
In mice and monkeys, within the dose range of 3-30mg/kg, Area Under the serum concentration-time Curve (AUC) and
Maximum Serum Concentration (C max ) increased proportionally with dose. MetMAb clearance in the linear dose range in
mice, rats, and monkeys was approximately 21, 19, and 13mL/day/kg, respectively. However, there was an observed
increase in clearance at the lower dose of 0.5mg/kg. Within the range of 3-30mg/kg, beta half-life was approximately 3-6
days. The initial volume of distribution of MetMAb approximated serum volume of each species. Based on allometric
scaling, human clearance was estimated to be 10mL/day/kg. Using species invariant time methods, human clearance and
terminal half-life in the dose-proportional exposure range was estimated to be approximately 5.5mL/day/kg and 10days
respectively.
Conclusion.
Within the dose range of 3-30mg/kg, MetMAb displayed linear PK. PK data in mice, rats, and monkeys suggests that the
clearance of MetMAb is approximately 2X faster than what is reported for bivalent glycosylated antibodies. A Phase I
clinical trial of MetMAb is ongoing and evaluation of the PK data will allow comparison of the two methods used to estimate
PK parameters in humans.
